list_definition.definition: an undertaking or scheme that involves some risk

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Every day the child ventured further into the forest.

list_definition.definition: to dare (to do (something), especially to say (something))

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He ventured to kiss her hand
I ventured (to remark) that her skirt was too short.
He decided to venture all his money on the scheme.

list_ex_of_english: Unlike the personal desire for the realization of an ideal, approval of democracy as a collective venture is more circumstantially than diffusely determined.
Indeed, they could have been even more ambitious and ventured further into the territory of development beyond the age of four years.
One might venture that the new science either responded to or was influenced by trends in opera houses and concert rooms.
To the extent we were linked with them in that joint venture, their history is ours and ours theirs.
Under the stimulus of quantum mechanics, the independent discoverers were each venturing into what turned out to be new territory for both disciplines.
Such an analysis was more subversive in thinkers who ventured to apply it to the internal structure of the state.
Of course these moments are a crucial aspect of our delight, and can be a rich source for interpretative ventures.
For, serious doubts may be raised about the viability of the doxastic venture model.
